Shi Zhimang, whose surname was Kang, was a person from Luoyang.
In his youth, when his family was invited to a Buddhist assembly, he was delighted and did not let go. He then left home to become a monk at Longxing Temple in Yingchuan.

The Biography of Lingtan of Hualin Temple in Yangzhou, Tang Dynasty. Shi Lingtan, with the surname Wu, was from Wenhui in Taiyuan.
He was a great-grandson of Empress Wu Zetian.

His mother, Lady Xiahou, had a dream before giving birth to Tan, in which a divine monk gave her a precious mirror, clear inside and out, and said:

In this way, he delighted in learning without rest, and his understanding of the books of the Three Teachings became even more profound.
However, he always lamented the decaying house and vowed to enter the empty gate. Having already prepared the provisions for the Great Vehicle, he would finally reach the realm of nirvana.
At that time, the flourishing teaching of Chan Master Shenhui of Hedong in Luoyang was about to cover up the light of Puzhao and gradually eclipse the way of Master Xiu. Tan went to study with him.
Shenhui employed skillful means to guide him, and Tan suddenly saw his mind. Shenhui silently accepted him and allowed him to serve as his attendant.
His parents were unable to turn his mind back.
Flying and tossing, not bound, from beginning to end, grinding and polishing, able to break through doubts and obstructions.
In the first year of Tianbao, he summoned Tan and said:
I have a single phrase that has been passed down from ancestor to ancestor to Caoxi. Caoxi entrusted it to me, and you should receive it carefully.
I will have difficulties.

Tan then went to Fuchasha Temple in Luzhou to read the great canon.
Later, he heard that National Teacher Zhong was summoned from Nanyang, and in the fifth year of Dali he went to pay respects to him.

He traveled to Liangyuan, where Prime Minister Tian Gong Shenguang made offerings.

Biography of Yizhe of the Buddha's Cave Cliff in Mount Tiantai of the Tang Dynasty Biography of Yizhe of the Buddha's Cave Cliff in Mount Tiantai of the Tang Dynasty Shi Yizhe, with the secular surname Changsun, was from Chang'an, Jingzhao.

He was fond of classics and histories, especially Buddhist scriptures, considering them to be in accord with his mind.
One day, he abandoned his family property and followed Huizhong of Niutou Mountain, who was called the Sixth Patriarch of Niutou.
At the beginning, Bodhidharma of India brought the essence of Buddhism to China, and those who transmitted his teachings were Caoxi Neng and Songshan Xiu.
Those who studied under Neng were called the Southern School, and those who studied under Xiu were called the Northern School.
And Xinzu further transmitted his teachings to Huirong, who received them and lived on Niutou Mountain, with his disciples transmitting and teaching them.
Thus, the Dharma mind has the study of Niutou.

Having transmitted the Way of Zhizhe, after contemplating it for a long time, he considered that there are no things in heaven and earth, and he has no things. Although there are no things, he has never been without things.
This means that sages are like shadows, and the common people are like dreams. Who is there for life and death?
The sage can, by this, alone illuminate and be the master of myriad things. I know this.

He then traveled south to Tiantai and arrived at the Buddha's Cave Cliff. He covered himself with vines and lay on fallen leaves, drank from the mountain stream, and ate wild fruits to fill his emptiness. Tigers and leopards became his guests, and deer became his followers. He was as still as a withered tree.
Later, woodcutters saw him and told each other. Those who admired his Way said:
The Way has not yet had disciples.
They gathered to build rooms, draw Buddhas, and settle monks, and it became a monastery.
Therefore, since the Yuanhe period, the transmission of the Way has been called the Buddha Cave School, and the name Buddha Cave began with Zuo.
He sat in one place for forty years. Although high officials and famous nobles brought letters to pay respects and make offerings, Zuo never responded or rose to greet them.
At that time, in the summer of the gengxu year, on the thirteenth day of the last month, he called his disciples and said:
You should strive for it!
On the fifteenth day of the month, he sat and passed away.
That night, people on the mountain heard what sounded like a mountain collapsing. In the morning, they looked up and saw colorful clouds hovering over the cliff.
The elders all wept and said:
The master has died!
They looked and found it to be true.
In total, Zuo was a monk for twenty years. He passed away at the age of fifty-eight.

On the twenty-third day of the third month in the thirteenth year, he bathed, burned incense, sat upright on a rope bed, entrusted the assembly of the time, and suddenly passed away.
